content: How can I help you today?

I guess I'm here because my wife pushed me to come. Things have been really difficult at home with our son acting out, and it's putting a lot of strain on our marriage. Honestly, I don’t even know where to start or if this will help, but I want to try for my family's sake.

It sounds like things have been really challenging for you lately, especially with your family and your son acting out. It's clear you care deeply about your family and want to make an effort for them, even though you're feeling uncertain about how to move forward. What's been the hardest part of all this for you?

The hardest part is feeling like everything is falling apart, and I don’t know how to fix it. I feel helpless when it comes to my son—I don’t know how to help him. It’s frustrating, and on top of that, I feel like my relationship with my wife is crumbling under the pressure. I don’t even know where to begin to make things better.

That feeling of helplessness, combined with the pressure of holding everything together, sounds overwhelming. You're trying to navigate a difficult situation with your son while also feeling the strain it’s putting on your marriage—that's a lot to juggle. The fact that you're here shows how much you care about making things better for your family. What do you think might help you feel a bit more in control or supported right now?

I honestly don’t know what might help. I feel like I’ve tried everything, but nothing seems to work. Maybe just understanding why my son is acting out or learning how to help him would be a start. I also feel like my wife and I are barely communicating anymore, so that’s something else that needs fixing, but I don’t even know if we’re on the same page anymore.

There’s a lot weighing on you—the desire to understand what’s going on with your son and how to help him, and the worry about the growing distance between you and your wife. It seems like you’re carrying so much responsibility and searching for ways to reconnect and make progress, even though it feels out of reach right now. What would be most meaningful to work on first—understanding your son or finding ways to strengthen communication with your wife?

Honestly, I think both are important, but I feel like if I could understand and help my son, it might take some of the pressure off my wife and me. I hate feeling like I'm failing him and her at the same time. Maybe starting with my son could help us all as a family.

Focusing on your son sounds like a meaningful first step, especially if it feels like helping him could ease some of the tension for everyone in your family. You clearly care deeply about being there for him and your wife, even when it feels like you’re struggling. What do you think might be going on with your son that’s causing him to act out? Or, are there particular moments or behaviors that stand out to you recently?

Well, he's been having a lot of outbursts, especially when things don't go his way. It feels like he's always angry or frustrated, and I can't seem to figure out what’s really bothering him. I don't know if it's something happening at school or if we’re doing something wrong at home, but I feel like every day is a constant battle with him.

Those outbursts and constant battles sound both exhausting and confusing for you, especially without knowing what’s causing them. You’re trying to understand what’s underneath his frustration, whether it’s school, something at home, or something else entirely—and that shows how much you want to help him. Do you think it could help to try talking with your son about how he’s feeling, or have you noticed any patterns during these outbursts that might give you more clues?

When I try to talk to him, he usually just shuts down or gets more upset, which makes it even harder to know what’s going on in his head. As for patterns, it often happens when we ask him to do something he doesn’t want to do, like homework or chores. I just keep wondering if I’m doing something wrong as a parent, or if there’s a bigger issue here.

It sounds like you're really trying to reach him, but his responses make it tough to get through, especially during those moments when you ask him to do things like homework or chores. You're reflecting on your parenting and questioning if there's a bigger issue—that shows how deeply you care and want to support him. These situations can feel so discouraging, but it’s clear you’re putting thought into understanding and connecting with your son. Would it be helpful to explore ways to approach these situations differently, or are there other perspectives you’d like to consider first?

Honestly, I feel like I’ve tried everything I can think of, and nothing seems to work. I’m open to hearing new ideas or strategies, though, because whatever I’m doing just isn’t enough. I just want to figure out how to help him and stop feeling like I’m failing him as a parent.

It’s tough to feel like you’re doing everything you can and still not seeing the results you hope for. You’re open to exploring new approaches, which shows a lot of strength and love for your son—even when you're feeling down about your efforts. Before diving into strategies, is there anything else you’d like to share about how this has been affecting you or what you’ve already tried? Sometimes understanding that part can help figure out what might work better moving forward.

I’ve tried talking to him calmly, giving him space when he gets upset, even setting up a reward system for when he does things without a fight—but none of it really seems to stick. I’m so drained from trying all these things and still not seeing much change. It’s like I’m constantly second-guessing myself, and I’m afraid that somehow I’m just not cut out to do this right.

You’ve put a great deal of thought and effort into helping your son, from calm conversations to rewards, but not seeing change has left you feeling drained and questioning your abilities. It's understandable to feel unsure and second-guess yourself when so much energy goes into trying and not seeing results. The fact that you are still here, still looking for ways to support your son, really shows how committed and caring you are as a parent—even when it’s incredibly hard. Would it be helpful to take a moment and reflect on any small wins or strengths you’ve seen in your parenting, even if they feel small right now? Or, if you're ready, we could explore new ways to approach these challenges. Your thoughts?

I’m not sure I can even think of any wins right now… it feels like everything’s been such an uphill battle. Maybe we should explore some new approaches, because I don’t know how much longer I can keep on like this without things changing.

It takes a lot to be open to exploring new approaches, especially when you're feeling worn out and like things haven’t been working. Your determination to keep going despite feeling depleted speaks volumes about how much you care for your son and your family. Before we dive into exploring some ideas, is there anything else weighing on your mind that you’d like to talk about?

It means a lot that you're willing to open up about all this, even if it's hard to see the way forward right now. Let’s explore some strategies together, one step at a time, and try to find something that can start to make a difference—whether that’s for your son, your family, or even just for you personally. Where do you feel ready to begin?

Would it be helpful to begin by focusing on practical ways to manage those moments when your son has outbursts, or would you like to start looking at ways to create space for yourself to recharge and cope with everything you’re dealing with? Both could make a difference, and it’s your choice where to start.
